channel.title: Packets
channel.description: When someone makes a rsc private server bot is the auto catch done by packets? If it is can someone explain the process of this to me?

item.title: Packets
item.dc:creator: @Officer-Ahole Officer-Ahole
item.description:
@Officer-Ahole wrote:

[quote=“ownagesbot, post:12, topic:325427”][quote author=Officer-Ahole link=topic=421738.msg3101062#msg3101062 date=1263703948]

[quote author=ownagesbot link=topic=421738.msg3100940#msg3100940 date=1263699000]

There are basically two main packets that are used for attack. Packet 57 is player-to-player attack and packet 73 is player-to-npc attack. Both of thses packets are created by the client when the correct menu id is picked and when recived by the server, the packets are handled in Attackhandler.java.

Attached to these packets are “actionTypes” which contains data that is to be sent with the packet. The default action type that is sent with both these packets is the server index of the npc or player. When the server recieves the packet, it first gets the npc or player depending on their server index and then dose whatever is coded into attackhandler.
[/quote]‘Packet 57’ kind of implies a packet number, not really true. Packets generally consist of an opcode (or packet id) and operand(s) (parameters, or additional data), the opcode is always first, this allows for identification of the packet. This is what adu is referring to. You must also realise that most servers have modified packet id’s because they for some reason believe it stops people botting. /retards

It’s a quick way of identifying amateur botters (as they only look for the client version and nothing else). you can set the original packet id (57) to do the same action as the modified one, but log those who uses the original.
[/quote]Or you could use proper prevention from the offset, that way you don’t have to ban any of your players, nor do you have to put up with botters.[/quote]

well like you said, they’re retards. what can you really expect from them?

Read full topic

item.title: Packets
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

[quote=“Officer-Ahole, post:11, topic:325427”][quote author=ownagesbot link=topic=421738.msg3100940#msg3100940 date=1263699000]

There are basically two main packets that are used for attack. Packet 57 is player-to-player attack and packet 73 is player-to-npc attack. Both of thses packets are created by the client when the correct menu id is picked and when recived by the server, the packets are handled in Attackhandler.java.

Attached to these packets are “actionTypes” which contains data that is to be sent with the packet. The default action type that is sent with both these packets is the server index of the npc or player. When the server recieves the packet, it first gets the npc or player depending on their server index and then dose whatever is coded into attackhandler.
[/quote]‘Packet 57’ kind of implies a packet number, not really true. Packets generally consist of an opcode (or packet id) and operand(s) (parameters, or additional data), the opcode is always first, this allows for identification of the packet. This is what adu is referring to. You must also realise that most servers have modified packet id’s because they for some reason believe it stops people botting. /retards

It’s a quick way of identifying amateur botters (as they only look for the client version and nothing else). you can set the original packet id (57) to do the same action as the modified one, but log those who uses the original.[/quote]Or you could use proper prevention from the offset, that way you don’t have to ban any of your players, nor do you have to put up with botters.

Read full topic

item.title: Packets
item.dc:creator: @Officer-Ahole Officer-Ahole
item.description:
@Officer-Ahole wrote:

[quote=“ownagesbot, post:10, topic:325427”][quote author=adu link=topic=421738.msg3100336#msg3100336 date=1263670208]
There are basically two main packets that are used for attack. Packet 57 is player-to-player attack and packet 73 is player-to-npc attack. Both of thses packets are created by the client when the correct menu id is picked and when recived by the server, the packets are handled in Attackhandler.java.

Attached to these packets are “actionTypes” which contains data that is to be sent with the packet. The default action type that is sent with both these packets is the server index of the npc or player. When the server recieves the packet, it first gets the npc or player depending on their server index and then dose whatever is coded into attackhandler.
[/quote]‘Packet 57’ kind of implies a packet number, not really true. Packets generally consist of an opcode (or packet id) and operand(s) (parameters, or additional data), the opcode is always first, this allows for identification of the packet. This is what adu is referring to. You must also realise that most servers have modified packet id’s because they for some reason believe it stops people botting. /retards[/quote]

It’s a quick way of identifying amateur botters (as they only look for the client version and nothing else). you can set the original packet id (57) to do the same action as the modified one, but log those who uses the original.

Read full topic

@adu wrote:

There are basically two main packets that are used for attack. Packet 57 is player-to-player attack and packet 73 is player-to-npc attack. Both of thses packets are created by the client when the correct menu id is picked and when recived by the server, the packets are handled in Attackhandler.java.

Attached to these packets are “actionTypes” which contains data that is to be sent with the packet. The default action type that is sent with both these packets is the server index of the npc or player. When the server recieves the packet, it first gets the npc or player depending on their server index and then dose whatever is coded into attackhandler.

item.title: Packets
item.dc:creator: @meatstick meatstick
item.description:
@meatstick wrote:

dragonmon12:

I’v been trying this out and I notice it seems the packet changes for a different spawn but still the same NPC. I assuming auto attackers are not done with packets? I also tried to compair the packets and they look nothing alike.

yes they are.

item.title: Packets
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

ye although most autocatchers use packets indirectly. Most are client modifications that manipulate already existing methods in the client (such as methods for walking/attacking yadayada). And of course those methods work by sending the correct packets.

Read full topic
